linesOfText.text: The meadow was awash with life
A brand new season brings,
Butterflies dancing flower to flower
And melodies from those who sing.
Chirp chirp here, buzz buzz there,
Ants marching fierce and proud,
While woven deep within such splendor
A young boy spoke aloud.
Talking of the many things
He felt so deep inside;
Sadness, fear and hopelessness
Where once existed pride.
Pride in how he'd felt each day
When looking in the mirror;
The friendships, fun, and carefree life
He'd always held so dear.......
Jack liked to run and swim
And skate around the blocks,
Catching raindrops on his tongue,
And wearing mismatched socks.
But even though those things were fun
And precious as could be,
Jack chose to spend his days alone
Beneath the old Oak Tree.
Watching as the world passed by
Like clouds of faded glory.
All the while wishing for
A place to laugh and play.
Not alone, but with new friends
Who wouldn't point and stare,
But rather treat him equally
With love, respect and care.
Yet that was nothing but a dream
He knew would not come true.
Crying, as he turned to hug
The only friend he knew.
He'd found the tree in winters grasp
While walking in the snow,
Natures blanket ever so thick
Nothing had seemed to grow
Except one tree, a massive old thing,
Standing sentry all alone;
The moment in which Jack decided
That this would be his home.
Yes, what a perfect match they were
In that special time and place,
For the bark of the tree was rough and scarred
Like the skin was on his face.....
Skin that, no matter how he tried,
Still burnt him like the sun,
Once again reliving the memory
He never could outrun.
The day the accident happened
And how it changed his life;
Two years of everlasting pain
Cruelty, shame and strife
Brought about by Jack's pursuit
Of thrill seeking desires;
Yet none had been more careless
Than the ones involving Fire.
Pouring gas lines on the ground,
Then with a little spark,
He'd watch the flames erupt and race
While sitting in the dark....
"How fantastic", he had thought,
Though knowing all along
The danger he'd been warned of...
But how had it gone wrong?
Terribly wrong, for in a flash
What seemed a fun filled place
Turned to something painful
As flames licked at his face.
"Daddy, Daddy", Jack had cried
While running toward the door,
Fighting through the thick black smoke
Until he knew no more....
"Yes, what a tragic day" Jack thought
Still cuddled with the tree,
Longing for the days of old
And how it used to be.
"Oh, I wish that I could go", Jack said,
"To a fun and magical place
Where I'd fit in and have true friends
Who wouldn't make fun of my face".
"Is that so", a rumbling voice asked,
"Although I'm really not surprised."
Then suddenly its branches became hands,
And there appeared a set of eyes.
Eyes that danced with all the promise
He'd dreamt, but couldn't touch.
Heartfelt things, like love and kindness,
The ones needed so much.
"Don't be afraid", the tree whispered softly.
"My name is Oakley and I am your friend,
Since the day you first hugged me
And will be to the end
You see, I've listened to your troubles
And never once complained,
Kept you cool in the summer
And sheltered you from the rain.
But mostly I have felt
All the pain within your heart
And in those times of loneliness
We've never been apart.
I know just how you feel, Jack",
Oakley's eyes brimming with tears,
"For I've been here alone and scarred
Going on one hundred years....
No children wanting to laugh and play
From mornings first breath till dark,
No one to climb and swing from my branches
Nor etch sweet names in my bark.
But now I desire to grant your wish,
For I know of a special place,
One in where nature shall open the doors
To beauty, understanding and grace.
Now hurry my friend, run through this gate;
Within you'll find a great light",
And, closing his eyes, Jack raced forward
Believing with all of his might....
"You must be Jack; we've been waiting for you,"
Came a voice like a cool summer breeze,
Soft and inviting; and now he saw her
Sitting beneath the trees
A snow-white squirrel, smiling a smile
Bright as a thousand suns,
And in that moment Jack knew in his heart
His dream had only begun.
Before him towered a magnificent Forest
Of luscious light green flecked with gold,
But then what he heard, was ever so precious
A treasure to truly behold:
A trio of animals singing a chorus
"Welcome, dear Jack, to our home,
A place of friendship, togetherness and fun
Where no one is ever alone...."
There were silver foxes, with long bushy tails,
Rabbits and chipmunks, a family of snails,
Turtles and wolves, bears and a moose,
Raccoons and badgers, deer and a goose,
Ducks and swans with beautiful feathers
And a symphony of crickets
playing music together...
Then they spent the rest of the day
Laughing and playing games.
But how could that be", Jack suddenly wondered,
"When everyone wasn't the same?"
A fox was missing an ear and a tail,
A bear, some fur on its back;
One of the swans had an elegant white wing
While its other was scarred and black.
A three-legged wolf, a disfigured deer;
Yes many had been burned somehow.
But when asking the squirrel, she merely replied,
"You'll have to ask the Owl."
"Strange", Jack thought, "to ask a question
From someone when they are asleep."
Especially the Owl, who right from the start
Had not made a sound nor a peep.
"Now that's a hoot", the Owl merrily laughed
As if hearing a real funny joke.
"In fact, my dear child, I've listened quite clearly
To every word that you've spoke.
Each beat of your heart I hear and feel
As if my very own.
Each tear that you've cried, I've felt on my face;
Every sorrow I have known.
Yes Jack, I know your thoughts;
The troubles that you've gone through
But never has there been a day
That I've not been with you.
But now I wish to tell you
All the answers that you seek;
Open up those hidden doors
That you have locked up for keeps...
Help you to rediscover
All the ways which you inspire;
Open your eyes to all the beauty
You believe was taken by fire.
So listen to my story, Jack,
of how we came to be,
And, though half blind, I'll paint a picture
With words that you can see
It was summer time in the Forest
At a time in my young life,
When I'd been suffering though changes
Brought on by judgement and strife.
A hunter had blinded me
And, even though I did my best,
The fact that I was different
Truly put me to the test.
Friends I thought I had
Very quickly disappeared,
While the others from a distance
Had only laughed and sneered.
So all I did was sit and cry
Beneath an old oak tree,
Speaking of my many troubles
And wishing I could be...
Far away from there,
Where I wouldn't be a joke.
And that's about the time
When I smelled the dreaded smoke!
Yes, something was burning,
So I raced off to see
All my fellow foresters
Racing back to me.
The roaring of the flames
Was muffling their cries.
Then out of the blue
There came a great sigh,
Soothing like summer
Inviting like rain,
He opened his trunk
And called us by name.
Yes, Oakley saved our lives that day,
Losing much with no return;
And through the years I came to find
There was lessons to be learned.
Children are a funny lot,
The way in which they think;
Believe they can change the world
With nothing but a blink.
All the things they find unworthy
Any cannot comprehend,
Thinking that if someone's different
They just can't be your friend.
But then, as you grow older,
Clouded eyes begin to see
That underneath it all
They're the same as you and me.
But now its time for you to go,
And though it may not seem,
The troubles you now have
Shall fade away as if a dream.
Yes, of course you'll always look different
And carry a scar or two
But don't ever think, not for a minute
That this will ever change you.
For its not what's on the outside;
There's nothing more than skin.
We're all created equal, Jack;
Who we are comes from within.
"Goodbye our friend, and don't forget
The treasure in which you are."
"I won't" Jack smiled, touching his heart,
"I know you'll never be far."
The meadow whispered promises
She felt but couldn't see.
Every feeling told her
This is where she ought to be.
All day long she'd searched and searched
For something fun to do,
But luckier would be if she
Could make a friend or two.
She found him sleeping like an angel,
A smile upon his face,
Making it a moment in
A special time and place.
Kneeling down, she softly spoke,
"Do you want to play?",
Reminding Jack of friends he'd met
In a land far far away.
It was then he realized
That it must have been a dream.
But Oakley, the owl and squirrel,
So real they had seemed.
Suddenly the air was pierced
By a loud chattering sound,
And that is when he saw her
Racing across the ground.
A very treasured friend
Yet could it really be?
Then the squirrel stopped and winked
Before running up a tree.
"Want to play?", she asked again,
Gently touching Jack's hand.
And in that moment all he'd learned
Was easy to understand.
Her eyes held acceptance
Without a trace of fear,
And looking into them
Was just like looking into a mirror.
For what Jack saw reflected back
Was absolute pure joy,
Once again believing
He was just a normal boy.
THE END.
By Matthew Scroggins
